history.content:
You can only receive units for only one of these classes, and if you take both, only the first one you take will give you units (and I think only the first one will factor into your UC-computed GPA). The Academic Guide states under the CS 70 entry that "Students will receive no credit for [Computer Science] 70 after taking Mathematics 55." and the other way around for Math 55.

However, if you take both, only CS 70 will factor into your declaration GPA, regardless of which order you take them in. (Unless you're a math/applied math major, in which case I'm not sure.)

---

You can take what you want but Math 55 will not count for declaration unless you are a Math/Applied Math double major (EECS Policy) 

Taking both classes though will be perhaps boring they cover similar material, though CS 70 covers more material

children.subject: You won't get any units for CS 70 but hypothetically you could ... Its discouraged but not banned by EECS ... They are supposed to be rather different classes (like EE16a and Math 54 are both Linear Algebra but are rather different classes)

No, the Math 55 course on your transcript will have a "G5" code next to it. This means the units will not contribute to your total units for graduation, and the grade points earned will not contribute to your GPA.
can i take math 55 after cs70 for the gpa boost?

history.content: Are we allowed to take both for credit (e.g take Math 55 before CS 70), or can we only take CS 70 if we wish to declare the CS major?
history.subject: Math 55 and CS 70

history.content: Are we allowed to take both for credit (e.g take Math 55 as preparation for CS 70), or can we only take CS 70 if we wish to declare the CS major?
history.subject: Math 55 and CS 70
